snippet: In the Democratic Republic of Congo, the French term délestage is used to describe power cutoffs, but when applied to food shortages, it illustrates a stark reality.
abstract: Margin of survival for the people of the Democratic Republic of Congo is so slim that the the word 'delestage,' French term used for rolling power blackouts, is used to describe the availability of food as well as electricity; most people in Kinshasa, including children, eat only every other day, and the International Food Policy Research Institute reports that half of the country is considered undernourished.
lead_paragraph: In the Democratic Republic of Congo, the French term délestage is used to describe power cutoffs, but when applied to food shortages, it illustrates a stark reality.

headline.seo: In Congolese Capital, ‘Power Cut’ Applies to Food
headline.main: For Congo Children, Food Today Means None Tomorrow
headline.print_headline: For Congo Children, Food Today Means None Tomorrow
